biogHists.text:
KPFA-FM

KPFA-FM in Berkeley was an influential participant in the development of the Bay Area as a national center for new music. It gained an international reputation for its music programming early on, after being founded in 1949. Up until 1992, its Music Directors were always composers or critics in the classical music field. From 1969-1992, composer Charles Amirkhanian (Executive & Artistic Director of Other Minds) served as Music Director for KPFA. During his tenure the station initiated a number of unusual series, one of which was then the longest-running continuous program on avant-garde music in American radio history (Ode to Gravity, 1970-1995). Aside from the contemporary music programming the station was known for, it also broadcast a variety of programs focusing on bluegrass, opera, world music, jazz, folk, pop, and gospel; many recordings of which are also contained within the collection.

Other Minds

Other Minds (OM) is a non-profit organization in San Francisco dedicated to the encouragement and propagation of contemporary music in all its forms through multiple outlets including a yearly festival, an artist residency program, a record label, preservation project, and a radio program on KALW, San Francisco.

From the guide to the KPFA-FM Music Dept. audio collection, 1949-1995, (Other Minds Archives)

<objectXMLWrap>

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Edward Zold papers, 1993-1997.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Includes correspondence, meeting minutes, conference materials from the International Conference on AIDS, draft publications, press releases, and videotapes, documenting Zold's work with ACT UP Golden Gate, and illustrating how he influenced AIDS health policy, on a local as well as federal level. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:85015643</recordOrigin>

                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Fabilli, Mary,</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Hawley, Robert, 1929-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>KPFA (Radio station : Berkeley, Calif.)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Mary Fabilli correspondence with Dorothy and Robert Hawley, 1969-2011.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Contains letters, greeting cards, publications, and photographs from Fabilli concerning everyday life, her poetry, and information about William Everson. Includes a copy of "Mary Fabilli : 1914- a literary life," an autobiographical article about her literary influences. Also includes 11 color photographs (5 x 3.5 in.) of William Everson being interviewed by Eric Bauersfeld of KPFA Radio. Also present at the interview were artist Dan Stolpe, and Dorothy and Robert Hawley. Other photographs include Mary Fabilli, Lili Fabilli, Robert and Dorothy Hawley. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of California, Berkeley</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.abstract: Contains letters, greeting cards, publications, and photographs from Fabilli concerning everyday life, her poetry, and information about William Everson. Also includes 11 color photographs (5 x 3.5 in.) of William Everson being interviewed by Eric Bauersfeld of KPFA Radio. Also present at the interview were artist Dan Stolpe, and Dorothy and Robert Hawley. Other photographs include Mary Fabilli, Lili Fabilli, Robert and Dorothy Hawley.

                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of California, Berkeley</namePart>
                     <role>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Mass Media and Culture</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Special Collections, University of Maryland Libraries, Hornbake Library, College Park, MD 20742. Tel: 301-405-9212, Fax: 301-314-2709, Email: askhornbake@umd.edu</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <corpname>Pacifica Foundation</corpname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Pacifica Foundation Records</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1946-1991</unitdate>
                  <unitdate>1950-1980</unitdate>
                  <physdesc>13.50 linear feet</physdesc>
                  <unitid>NPBA 91-195</unitid>
                  <physloc>Room 3216 (Big Room):25:C:Room 3216 (Big Room) 25 : D : </physloc>
                  <abstract>Founded in 1946 by Lewis Hill, Eleanor McKinney and others as a noncommercial, educational, cultural radio in the San Francisco Bay area, the Pacifica Foundation has continued to flourish as a completely listener-supported radio network.  The goal behind having listener support was to insure a grass-roots forum that would support diversity, freedom of speech, and promote programs according to what the listeners want, not what a corporate sponsor wants.  Hill's strong beliefs in open communication and freedom of expression helped Pacifica set precedents concerning freedom of speech in broadcasting.  Besides the pioneer station, KPFA (Berkeley), Pacifica radio consists of KPFK (Los Angeles), WBAI (New York), KPFT (Houston), and WPFW (Washington, DC).  The collection traces the founding of Pacifica and the development of the listener-support system for radio.</abstract>
                  <abstract>Founded in 1946 by Lewis Hill, Eleanor McKinney and others as a noncommercial, educational, cultural radio in the San Francisco Bay area, the Pacifica Foundation has continued to flourish as a completely listener-supported radio network.  The goal behind having listener support was to insure a grass-roots forum that would support diversity, freedom of speech, and promote programs according to what the listeners want, not what a corporate sponsor wants.  Hill's strong beliefs in open communication and freedom of expression helped Pacifica set precedents concerning freedom of speech in broadcasting.  Besides the pioneer station, KPFA (Berkeley), Pacifica radio consists of KPFK (Los Angeles), WBAI (New York), KPFT (Houston), and WPFW (Washington, DC).  The collection traces the founding of Pacifica and the development of the listener-support system for radio.</abstract>
                  <abstract>Founded in 1946 by Lewis Hill, Eleanor McKinney and others as a noncommercial, educational, cultural radio in the San Francisco Bay area, the Pacifica Foundation has continued to flourish as a completely listener-supported radio network.  The goal behind having listener support was to insure a grass-roots forum that would support diversity, freedom of speech, and promote programs according to what the listeners want, not what a corporate sponsor wants.  Hill's strong beliefs in open communication and freedom of expression helped Pacifica set precedents concerning freedom of speech in broadcasting.  Besides the pioneer station, KPFA (Berkeley), Pacifica radio consists of KPFK (Los Angeles), WBAI (New York), KPFT (Houston), and WPFW (Washington, DC).  The collection traces the founding of Pacifica and the development of the listener-support system for radio.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Pacifica Foundation Records 1946-1991 1950-1980
resource.abstract: Founded in 1946 by Lewis Hill, Eleanor McKinney and others as a noncommercial, educational, cultural radio in the San Francisco Bay area, the Pacifica Foundation has continued to flourish as a completely listener-supported radio network.  The goal behind having listener support was to insure a grass-roots forum that would support diversity, freedom of speech, and promote programs according to what the listeners want, not what a corporate sponsor wants.  Hill's strong beliefs in open communication and freedom of expression helped Pacifica set precedents concerning freedom of speech in broadcasting.  Besides the pioneer station, KPFA (Berkeley), Pacifica radio consists of KPFK (Los Angeles), WBAI (New York), KPFT (Houston), and WPFW (Washington, DC).  The collection traces the founding of Pacifica and the development of the listener-support system for radio. Founded in 1946 by Lewis Hill, Eleanor McKinney and others as a noncommercial, educational, cultural radio in the San Francisco Bay area, the Pacifica Foundation has continued to flourish as a completely listener-supported radio network.  The goal behind having listener support was to insure a grass-roots forum that would support diversity, freedom of speech, and promote programs according to what the listeners want, not what a corporate sponsor wants.  Hill's strong beliefs in open communication and freedom of expression helped Pacifica set precedents concerning freedom of speech in broadcasting.  Besides the pioneer station, KPFA (Berkeley), Pacifica radio consists of KPFK (Los Angeles), WBAI (New York), KPFT (Houston), and WPFW (Washington, DC).  The collection traces the founding of Pacifica and the development of the listener-support system for radio. Founded in 1946 by Lewis Hill, Eleanor McKinney and others as a noncommercial, educational, cultural radio in the San Francisco Bay area, the Pacifica Foundation has continued to flourish as a completely listener-supported radio network.  The goal behind having listener support was to insure a grass-roots forum that would support diversity, freedom of speech, and promote programs according to what the listeners want, not what a corporate sponsor wants.  Hill's strong beliefs in open communication and freedom of expression helped Pacifica set precedents concerning freedom of speech in broadcasting.  Besides the pioneer station, KPFA (Berkeley), Pacifica radio consists of KPFK (Los Angeles), WBAI (New York), KPFT (Houston), and WPFW (Washington, DC).  The collection traces the founding of Pacifica and the development of the listener-support system for radio.

resource.source:
Houghton Library, Harvard College Library, Harvard University Harvard Depository

The majority of this collection is shelved offsite at the Harvard Depository. See access restrictions below for additional information.

Series VI, items (2014)-(2156) temporarily shelved at end of MS Stacks on Houghton P1 awaiting end-processing. [March 2011].

b, pf MS Mus 261 Moldenhauer, Hans, collector. The Moldenhauer Archives at Harvard University: Correspondence, literary manuscripts, sound recordings, and other material, 1873-2001. 59 boxes, 9 cartons (not end-processed) (50 linear ft.)

Collection materials are primarily in English and German, but also include some in French, Spanish, Dutch, Italian, Portugese, and other languages.

This collection is a portion of the Archives relating to 20th-century music, collected by the German-American musicologist, Hans Moldenhauer.
resource.title: The Moldenhauer Archives at Harvard University: Correspondence, literary                manuscripts, sound recordings, and other material, 1873-2001.
resource.abstract: This collection is a portion of the Archives relating to 20th-century music,                collected by the German-American musicologist, Hans Moldenhauer.
resource.displayEntry: The Moldenhauer Archives at Harvard University: Correspondence, literary manuscripts, sound recordings, and other material, 1873-2001.

resourceRelations.content: The Moldenhauer Archives at Harvard University: Correspondence, literary manuscripts, sound recordings, and other material, 1873-2001.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:173692738</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:WHi</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Pacifica Foundation.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>KPFA (Radio station : Berkeley, Calif.)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>KPFK (Radio station : Los Angeles, Calif.)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>WBAI Radio (New York, N.Y.)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>KPFT-FM (Radio station : Houston, Tex.)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Pacifica Foundation records, 1949-1987.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Records of the Pacifica Foundation, a non-profit foundation which pioneered listener-sponsored broadcasting and which operates five FM stations: KPFA, Berkeley, California; KPFK, Los Angeles, California; WBAI, New York City; KPFT, Houston, Texas; and WPFW, Washington, D.C. Coverage is best for programming and operations of the individual stations; these files include a fairly comprehensive collection of program guides for KPFA, KPFK, and WBAI, and operational material chiefly for KPFA and KPFK. Also pertaining to KPFA are 19 cartons of partially-processed news scripts, 1963-1973. Although the remainder of the collection pertains to Pacifica in general, there is little documentation on overall policymaking. Also included is material concerning investigations of Pacifica by the U.S. Senate and the FCC over alleged communist infiltration and the use of obscenity on the air. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Pacifica Foundation records, 1949-1987.
resource.abstract: Records of the Pacifica Foundation, a non-profit foundation which pioneered listener-sponsored broadcasting and which operates five FM stations: KPFA, Berkeley, California; KPFK, Los Angeles, California; WBAI, New York City; KPFT, Houston, Texas; and WPFW, Washington, D.C. Coverage is best for programming and operations of the individual stations; these files include a fairly comprehensive collection of program guides for KPFA, KPFK, and WBAI, and operational material chiefly for KPFA and KPFK. Also pertaining to KPFA are 19 cartons of partially-processed news scripts, 1963-1973. Although the remainder of the collection pertains to Pacifica in general, there is little documentation on overall policymaking. Also included is material concerning investigations of Pacifica by the U.S. Senate and the FCC over alleged communist infiltration and the use of obscenity on the air.
resource.extent: 23.0 c.f. (12 archives boxes and 19 record center cartons); plusadditions of 43.2 c.f.22 tape recordings,3 discs,100 photographs,57 negatives,12 transparencies, and1 poster.
resource.displayEntry: Pacifica Foundation. Pacifica Foundation records, 1949-1987.

resourceRelations.content: Pacifica Foundation. Pacifica Foundation records, 1949-1987.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>KPFA-FM Music Dept. audio collection</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1949-1995</unitdate>
                  <unitid>Consult organization's archives department.</unitid>
                  <origination>
                     <corpname>KPFA (Radio Station: Berkeley, Calif.)</corpname>
                  </origination>
                  <origination>
                     <corpname>Other Minds (organization)</corpname>
                  </origination>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>Approximately 4,700 items</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Other Minds Archives</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>San Francisco, CA 94103</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <abstract>Compiled from 1949 to 1995, this collection of primarily analog reel-to-reel audiotapes embodies decades of innovative new music radio programming, specialized in 20th Century new music, but whose content also reflects a variety of musical forms rarely represented by commercial media. The collection features live concert recordings, other musical recordings, interviews, performance art and symposia, covering artists whose backgrounds range from the classical conservatories to the counter-cultural underground movement of the 1960s.</abstract>
                  <langmaterial>
Languages represented in the collection: 
<language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: KPFA-FM Music Dept. audio collection 1949-1995
resource.abstract: Compiled from 1949 to 1995, this collection of primarily analog reel-to-reel audiotapes embodies decades of innovative new music radio programming, specialized in 20th Century new music, but whose content also reflects a variety of musical forms rarely represented by commercial media. The collection features live concert recordings, other musical recordings, interviews, performance art and symposia, covering artists whose backgrounds range from the classical conservatories to the counter-cultural underground movement of the 1960s.
resource.displayEntry: KPFA-FM Music Dept. audio collection, 1949-1995

resourceRelations.content: KPFA-FM Music Dept. audio collection, 1949-1995

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:227478134</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-UCB</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Webb, Catherine J.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Smith, Charles.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Interviews with Catherine J. Webb : transcripts, 1973-1974.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Fifty-four interviews conducted by Charles Smith, l973-l974. Subjects covered include early history of Nevada City, family history, Berkeley Arts and Crafts Co-op, her trip to Mississippi in l966-l967 to start a co-op among the blacks, involvement in various East Bay political and social activities, KPFA, the Albany Hill zoning crisis of l972, her son's work in the Philippines as a Peace Corps volunteer, l962-1966. Includes also selections from family letters and diaries. Subject index included with each interview. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of California, Berkeley</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Interviews with Catherine J. Webb : transcripts, 1973-1974.
resource.abstract: Fifty-four interviews conducted by Charles Smith, l973-l974. Subjects covered include early history of Nevada City, family history, Berkeley Arts and Crafts Co-op, her trip to Mississippi in l966-l967 to start a co-op among the blacks, involvement in various East Bay political and social activities, KPFA, the Albany Hill zoning crisis of l972, her son's work in the Philippines as a Peace Corps volunteer, l962-1966. Includes also selections from family letters and diaries. Subject index included with each interview.
resource.extent: Transcripts: 2 boxes (.8 linear ft.).Phonotapes: 5 sound cassettes : analog.
resource.displayEntry: Webb, Catherine J. Interviews with Catherine J. Webb : transcripts, 1973-1974.

resourceRelations.content: Webb, Catherine J. Interviews with Catherine J. Webb : transcripts, 1973-1974.

resource.abstract: Interviews with John H. Briones, William E. Colby, Herbert M. Evans and Frank Swett conducted by John M. Jencks and Ernest Lowe for radio station KPFA, Berkeley, 1964. With these: correspondence relative to the interviews and transcribing them.

Jencks and Ernest Lowe for the Regional Oral History Office, the Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley, California, 1971 : and related material, 1964-1971.
